item.title: ICYMI: TGA's Day Of The Devs Showcase Highlighted A Pair Of Upcoming Switch Indies
item.content:encoded:
We've already rounded up all of the Switch announcements from The Game Awards 2025, but that wasn't the only showcase that Mr Keighley served up this holiday season.

As ever, Day of the Devs was on hand to highlight a bunch of upcoming indies that we can look forward to in the next year or two. It was a slightly slimmer showing on the Switch front than we have seen in previous years (at least, as far as confirmed Switch releases go), but there were still two titles that have already announced a Switch (2) launch.

First up, we have Rockbeasts, a '90s "rock-and-roll management RPG", that sees you put in charge of a grunge rock band comprised of anthropomorphised wilderbeast... and a fish. It sounds like a lot, and it looks like it, too. The gameplay has a bit of everything — rhythm games, management sims, visual novels — and the whole thing has a visual style that looks like it's just stumbled out of a Bojack Horseman episode.

In short, we're very interested to find out more. Rockbeasts doesn't have a firm release date at the time of writing, but the devs did confirm that it will be launching on Switch 1 and 2. Rock on, dude!

The second Switch game showcased in the latest Day of the Devs was Demon Tides. You might remember this one from last year's DotD event, and yes, it still looks awesome. This is the next 3D platformer from Demon Turf dev Fabraz, combining super slick-looking movement with the most toe-tapping of hip-hop scores.

Once again, there's no Switch release date for this one just yet, though Fabraz has confirmed that Fangamer will be handling a physical release, so that's something to look forward to!

Naturally, there's every chance that we will see a fair few of the other games from the latest Day of the Devs showcase pop up on Switch at some point down the line. Switch 2 is still very much the new kid in town, so we'd be surprised if indie devs don't want to capitalise on its relative hotness and bring their titles over.

We've added the full Day of the Devs: The Game Awards 2025 Edition showcase below, so you can take a look at all the games revealed and make your own predictions about whether they will be heading to Switch or not.

What do you make of these two titles confirmed for Switch? Were there any others in the showcase that you're hoping will make the jump? Let us know in the comments.

item.title: Hogwarts Legacy Is Free to Add to Your Epic Games Store Library Through December 18
item.content:encoded:
A new Epic Games Store Holiday sale has just started, mere weeks after the Black Friday/Cyber Monday one, and it begins with a big freebie: Hogwarts Legacy. Avalanche Software's acclaimed open world third-person action/adventure game released in 2023 can be added permanently to your Epic Games Store library through December 18 at 5 PM.

Furthermore, Epic Games has partnered with publisher Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment (which might be sold to Netflix or Paramount Skydance, depending on which company gets Warner Bros.) to promote Hogwarts Legacy across its games. Players who spend at least two hours in the world of Hogwarts Legacy (via the Epic Games Store) by December 18 at 11 AM Eastern Time can earn the Chocolate Frog Back Bling in Fortnite. This, of course, also applies to those who may have previously purchased the game via the store and spent two or more hours in the game. Later in December, the Fortnite Shop will feature outfits and accessories inspired by the Wizarding World. Players can customize each outfit to represent one of the four Hogwarts houses: Gryffindor, Slytherin, Ravenclaw, and Hufflepuff.

Rocket League is also celebrating the Harry Potter franchise as part of its annual Frosty Fest event. In the Hogwarts House Rivalry, players earn points by playing matches while representing a house. Players will also be able to celebrate their favourite house with challenge rewards and shop items. More details will be announced later this month.

Hogwarts Legacy was the best-selling game in 2023, beating even Call of Duty that year. A Definitive Edition featuring additional content was reportedly in the works with the help of Rocksteady; however, Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment ultimately cancelled this project.

A sequel was officially confirmed to be WBIE's top priority, which was no surprise given its excellent sales (over 35 million units to date). Of course, it will take some time to materialize. Hogwarts Legacy was released in February 2023 and received support for a while; taking a guess, Avalanche Software could be targeting a launch for the sequel at some point in 2028.

You can also extend your phone’s visuals when taking a video call, plus play your favorite games remotely. This deal brings its price down to $57, but it’s likely going to expire soon. item.title: After a Relatively Quiet The Game Awards, Microsoft Says It Has a Packed Xbox Developer Direct Coming in January 2026
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft has confirmed plans for a significant Xbox Developer Direct showcase in January 2026 after a relatively quiet The Game Awards.

While Microsoft-owned Blizzard announced the next Diablo 4 expansion, and we got news that South of Midnight is coming to PlayStation 5 and Nintendo Switch 2, fans saw nothing of the new Fable, Forza, Gears of War, or Halo games confirmed to be coming out in 2026.

But in an interview with Variety, Microsoft president of game content and studios Matt Booty promised big things are coming next month.

“I can’t share exactly what’s there, but we’ve got a lot of stuff that we’re shipping next year. In fact, usually Dev Direct is about highlighting what’s coming up for the year ahead. This year, we’ve got more stuff coming up than we can fit in one show,” Booty teased.

“So I will tell you that Playground Games is going to be in the Dev Direct, but we’ll have more stuff next year to ship than we can fit into one Dev Direct show in January, which is a good place to be.”

So, what can we expect? If Playground Games is in the Dev Direct, it seems likely we’ll get a closer look at Forza Horizon 6 and, potentially, the next Fable game, both of which are in the works at the UK studio. Beyond that, perhaps we’ll see more of Gears of War: E-Day and Halo: Campaign Evolved, both of which are confirmed 2026 releases.

Xbox Games Series Tier List

Xbox Games Series Tier List

But, also based on Booty’s comments, perhaps Microsoft will follow up January’s Dev Direct with showcases that focus on individual games, just to make sure they get enough time in the spotlight.

“It’s going to be a real banner year for the brand and a banner year for some of our biggest franchises to show up across the industry,” Booty continued.

Perhaps we’ll also hear more on Microsoft’s hardware plans, which include a next-gen console that sounds a lot like a PC.

Be sure to check out everything announced at The Game Awards 2025 for more, as well as the winners list in full.

item.title: Go on then, break 4:Loop's roguelike-ish mechanics with teleporting berry mischief, says Left 4 Dead creator
item.content:encoded:
I have to say, it does tickle me that pretty much anyone involved with Left 4 Dead just seem to still want to make Left 4 Dead. The Anacrusis and Back 4 Blood both were made by folks who worked on the original co-op shooter, and now the original lead designer of it Mike Booth is back with yet another incarnation, 4:Loop, revealed at Geoff's Ads and Statues Evening. As part of that reveal, Booth took part in a little interview over on the PlayStation Blog where he touched on the game's roguelike mechanics, and how excited he is for people to break them.

Booth explained that he's been a fan of roguelikes since the original Rogue, and how the genre appeals to him because of the ways you can be creative in achieving certain goals. "Some runs even feel like you have such a great combination of tools that you 'break the game,'" Booth said, also noting that with 4:Loop he does still just want to let people "jump in and play."

We'll come back to that game breaking stuff in a moment, but first here's how Booth explains the core loop. Essentially, you and three of your buds need to try and destroy an alien mothership, with each mission you embark on letting you make different choices to improve equipment. Along the way, you might pick up certain items that help you out in tricky scenarios.

One such scenario Booth described was an instance where a playtester was trying to outrun a lethal beam of some sort that basically means game over if you can't get to the escape zone in time. Said playtester had picked up an item called a blink berry, which you can sort of throw like a grenade, and wherever it lands it'll teleport whatever it hits to somewhere random. So, the playtester threw it at themself, was teleported away, and made it to the escape zone in time.

"I built both of those game mechanics and had never even considered that strategy," Booth said. "I’m excited to see how our gaming community 'breaks the game' in other unexpected ways." Apparently there's bit of "meta-progression" where you learn things about the world and how it works that "give you an edge for your next run."

From the sounds of things it won't be a full-on roguelike, maybe more towards a roguelite, something to keep runs fresh rather than just taking hordes of aliens on over and over again. No release date attached to this one yet, so, just keep replaying Left 4 Dead like you I'm assuming you already do.

item.title: Apple AirPods Pro 3 Drops Below Its Black Friday Price, Now as Cheap as the Pro 2 on Sale
item.content:encoded:
Apple unveiled its latest pair of earbuds – the Apple AirPods Pro 3 – in September this year, and our audio experts loved the upgrades these brought. They launched at the standard $249 price, but we just spotted a deal that lets you pick them up for less today.

Amazon has now dropped the AirPods Pro 3 to $199, after taking 20% off, bringing the pair back to its lowest price ever. All shoppers get to enjoy free delivery with their purchase, and placing your orders today can help you get them just in time for Christmas. If you’ve been meaning to upgrade your audio gear, or surprise a music lover in your life this holiday season, now is the time to make the move.

See at Amazon

Impressive Sound, Better ANC Capabilities

These look quite similar to AirPods Pro 2, but feature a slightly redesigned shape with new foam-infused silicone ear tips for a better fit. The new acoustic architecture gives sound quality a boost, delivering rich, deep audio that lets you enjoy your favorite tracks and podcasts with detailed clarity. It lets you feel every instrument, with vivid vocals like never before.

Active noise cancellation capabilities have improved, too, as this pair is capable of removing up to 2x more unwanted noise than AirPods Pro 2; great for when you want to stay fully immersed in the moment with your favorite track playing. The ANC mode works well when you don’t want background sounds to distract you. You can enable it when you’re working in a busy cafe or trying to focus on an important task in the office. Of course, this level of noise blocking doesn’t work for every situation – sometimes it’s better to stay present and aware of what’s happening around. For that, there’s the transparency mode, which lets some ambient sound in.

Regardless of the mode, AirPods Pro 3 customize the sound signature for your unique ear geometry and fit with its next-generation Adaptive EQ. What’s more, these protect your hearing health, too. You can take an at-home hearing test that checks your hearing in a broader range of everyday conditions, or use the pair as a hearing aid when you need the voices around you amplified. Those often exposed to loud environmental noise can put them on to prevent hearing loss as well. Other health features include heart rate sensing, which monitors your heart rate, plus calories burned for up to 50 different workout types.

Another solid selling point is the Live Translation feature, which uses Apple Intelligence to offer real-time translation for face-to-face conversations around the world. Basically, the earbuds pick up on what someone is saying and translate it instantly, letting you reply in your preferred language using your iPhone or their AirPods. As for the battery life, you’ll enjoy up to 8 hours of listening on a single charge with Active Noise Cancellation on, and up to 10 hours in Transparency using the Hearing Aid feature.

This deal brings the price of this feature-packed pair to $199, from $249. It’s a big discount, sure, considering how these just launched, it’s still a welcome drop. It won’t last long, though, so it’s best to get your orders in quickly before it wraps up. Ordering now will also help you enjoy free shipping with your purchase!

item.title: CRKD Announces The 'Nitro Deck 2', Compatible With Switch And Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
Shipping Spring 2026

We've had mixed opinions on the CRKD Nitro Deck for the Switch, but now the company has come out swinging with a brand new iteration – and it's compatible with both Switch and Switch 2.

The Nitro Deck 2 starts shipping in Spring 2026 and looks to be a significant upgrade over the previous model. It seems the company has the Switch 2 in mind with this new product, but those still on the original Switch can still get in on the action. You'll just need to utilise the additional centrepiece to make up for the height difference, while turning the dial on the back to decrease the length of the chassis.

Otherwise, the Deck 2 has offset analogue sticks which, for the first time, aren't situation directly above and below the d-pad and face buttons. They utilise capacitor-based technology are said to be free from potential drifting issues. It also features additional back buttons, adjustable deadzones, turbo mode, and more.

The d-pad design and stick tops can also be swapped out, but be mindful that these additional parts are sold separately.

Pricing is confirmed at £89.99 for the Nitro Deck 2 itself, while any addition d-pad/stick packs are £19.99 each. Pre-orders are available now via the CRKD website.

item.title: Star Wars: Fate Of The Old Republic Announced, But Will It Skip Switch 2?
item.content:encoded:
Currently confirmed for "PC and Consoles"

Star Wars: Fate of the Old Republic was one of the most surprising reveals at this year's The Game Awards, marking a huge return to the RPG series that put Bioware on the map.

The original developer is nowhere to be seen, however, with this new title now in the hands of Arcanaut Studios, founded in July 2025. Its CEO, Casey Hudson, is heading up development for Fate of the Old Republic (FOTOR..?), having previously directed the original Knights of the Old Republic and the Mass Effect trilogy.

This is a pretty big deal, then. It's clear that the new game is early in development given how recent the studio itself was formed, and as such, no specific platforms have been confirmed beyond a rather vague "PC and Consoles". So we have no idea if this thing is heading to the Switch 2 or not, but we reckon it's a little too early to make the call either way.

The trailer itself gives us next to nothing, as you'd expect. It shows what is likely to be the main protagonist landing on a planet with two companions before making her way into a derelict crash site. There, she encounters a mysterious creature and ignites her lightsaber. That's it!

Lots of questions, then. Is this game even considered canon at this point? Our knowledge is a little rusty these days, admittedly, but our understanding is that the canon equivalent of the 'Old Republic' is now the 'High Republic'. All of that 'pre-Disney' stuff is now part of the 'Legends' continuity.

Still, it looks cool, and we'll be keeping a close eye on it in the months (and years) to come.

What did you make of Fate of the Old Republic? Would you like to see it on Switch 2? Let us know with a comment.

item.title: After a seven year wait, Bandai Namco's classic aerial combat series will return in 2026 with Ace Combat 8
item.content:encoded:
Unreal Engine 5-powered game gets first trailer at The Game Awards 2025.

Ace Combat 8: Wings of Theve is releasing in 2026, publisher Bandai Namco has revealed. The game, coming to PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X/S, and PC, was announced during last night's The Game Awards.

It's been seven years since Ace Combat 7 (and JPEG dog - if you know, you know), so this next entry is being developed on Unreal Engine 5 for the first time. Bandai Namco is promising an "emotionally charged" campaign, plus multiplayer modes, although firm details won't arrive until next year.

The first trailer for Ace Combat 8 can be viewed below:

In the campaign players will take on the role of an ace pilot (are there any fighter pilots who aren't ace?) in the fictitious Strangereal, with a fairly classic sounding plot that sees you fighting against the odds alongside three new pilots. Will you be able to be able to live up to the hopes of the people of the Federation of Central Usea? I assume yes, as it won't feel very heroic otherwise!

Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown released on PS4 and Xbox One back on 18th January, 2019. A PC version arrived two weeks later in February, while a Switch port was released onto Nintendo's hybrid console on 11th July, 2024.

item.title: What We Played – Skate Story, Megabonk and watching The Game Awards
item.content:encoded:
The morning after The Game Awards, and anyone over here in Europe is likely reaching for the caffeinated drinks right now. There were an amazing batch of announcements, including massive franchise entries like Star Wars: Fate of the Old Republic, through to exciting indies like Coven of the Chicken Foot. My highlight might be Star Wars: Galactic Racer, but then, I’m weird. I’ve been playing some great games this week, and that includes Aaero2 which I’ll have a review of next week, and the incredible Skate Story.

Aran was first up, and he’s been on an indie game tear, playing Death Howl, UNBEATABLE, and Aethermancer for review. He told us, “I didn’t really gel with Death Howl, unfortunately, despite it having some decent gameplay. UNBEATABLE is fun but the story mode is all over the place. The arcade mode is a much better experience. Aethermancer is shaping up to be a fun roguelike where you capture monsters to fight for you, but lose them at the end of a run. It makes you experiment with different party setups. I’ve also started Star Wars Outlaws, which I think I got as a present last Christmas. I’m still very early in the game but looking forward to exploring every inch of the map.”

Tuffcub stopped up late working on our TGA coverage with Tef, but that didn’t stop him from posting his stellar Terminator 2D: No Fate review, which he definitely enjoyed for its throwback 90s arcade charms. That was the pitch and it absolutely lived up to it.

Ade was next up, and he’s been playing Wizard of Legend 2 in local coop with Laura. He explains, “Apparently, the game wasn’t too well received back when it was launched but it’s great fun now! Actually, I shockingly – whisper it – find him quite endearing.”

When Laura wasn’t playing Wizard of Legend, she got up to more family making in Jurassic World Evolution 3, saying, “This week a baby T-Rex was born and frankly that’s trumps anything else anyone will tell you today!”

Jason told us that, “Megabonk has claimed me” which feels like a cry for help. He continued, “I’ve nearly got every achievement and am trying to beat the high scores of my mates. I’ve also played a little of World of Final Fantasy, as I want to replay it, but not as much as I want to be a skeleton on a skateboard.”

item.title: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 Drops Sizable Free ‘Thank You’ Update After Sweeping the TGA 2025 Floor; AMD FSR 4 Added
item.content:encoded:
Sandfall Interactive's Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 literally swept the floor during last night's The Game Awards 2025, winning nine out of ten of the prizes it got nominated for, including Game of the Year and Studio of the Year for its developer. It's a massive victory for a relatively small indie team that spent less than $10 million making this title.

As if gamers couldn't love them enough already, the French developer has now dropped the previously teased sizable (and free) new update, version 1.5, which adds new features like AMD FSR 4 on PC and even new content, such as Verso's Drafts, a new playable environment that takes the characters of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 to a brand-new location with new enemy encounters and surprises to discover. Verso's Drafts is located on the world map right next to Lumière and becomes accessible from Act III. Esquie's underwater ability is required to access the environment.

That's far from the only addition of the so-called 'Thank You' update. New Luminas and weapons have been added; there are new costumes for each member of the Expedition, giving players even more customization options; there are new boss battles for late-game players to overcome in the Endless Tower, variations of iconic bosses from the main game that are designed to be even more challenging.

The "Old Key" quest item has been added to the final area of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33. This specific item was previously only obtainable during the game's prologue, so this addition gives players a second chance to collect all journals within a single playthrough. New text and UI game localizations are available in Czech, Ukrainian, Latin American Spanish, Turkish, Vietnamese, Thai, and Indonesian, bringing the total number of supported languages to 19, with more to come, according to Sandfall.

Update 1.5 also introduces the following features:

  • Lumina Sets, which enable players to save up to 50 different Lumina loadouts, allowing them to adapt their fighting tactics at any moment.
  • An Abandon Battle option in the pause menu is available and it can now be opened in battle.
  • A Photo Mode is now in the game with plenty of settings and options for players to get creative with while capturing their favourite moments from the game. It's accessible at any time from the pause menu.
  • A HUD Scale setting has been added to the game so that players may adjust the size of in-game HUD elements from 80% to 120%.
  • Input remapping is available for controllers.
  • The game is now officially certified for the Steam Deck and ROG Xbox Ally.

There are, of course, plenty of bug fixes too. You can read the full changelog here.

item.title: Everything Announced at The Game Awards 2025
item.content:encoded:
The Game Awards 2025 has come and gone, and as you might expect, there were a ton of reveals, announcements, and new trailers during last night's ceremony. Here's everything that was shown off during The Game Awards this year!

The Free Shepherd kicks things off

The first trailer we got to see was for a rather cute-looking herding game by the name of The Free Shepherd. It's got Herdling vibes, and it lands on PC and PS5 in 2027.

Decrepit looks ideal for King's Field fans

If you like first-person dungeon crawlers like King's Field, Arx Fatalis, or the Might and Magic games, then Decrepit looks like it'll be for you. This one's coming to PC, and you can sign up for its playtest now.

Audio Mech is a musical adventure you can play tomorrow

Next up, it's a new game from the folks behind Audio Surf, and Audio Mech will let you set any music to the action, including streaming. A demo is coming to Steam tomorrow!

Pragmata finally has a release date

Capcom's weird action-strategy hybrid...thingy, Pragmata, finally has a release date. It's launching on April 24th on PC, PS5, Xbox Series X|S, and Switch 2, and a demo for consoles is available too!

Solasta 2 brings RPG goodness in March

Have you been hankering for some good old-fashioned Dungeons & Dragons-style dungeoneering? If so, then Solasta 2 is here to whet your appetite. It's launching into Early Access on March 12th.

Tankrat has...well, lots of tanks

Our next reveal brings post-apocalyptic Mad Max vibes along with it. Tankrat is a vehicular combat game that has a strong junkyard aesthetic, and it's coming to PC and PS5 in spring next year.

Bradley the Badger is an unexpectedly gory platformer

I'll admit I wasn't expecting Bradley the Badger's titular mammal to brutally stab one of his enemies through the gut during the debut trailer, but hey, surprises are fun! This ambitious-looking game is coming to PC via Steam.

Stupid Never Dies looks pleasingly old-school

Next up is a hack-and-slash-style action game with a graffiti-inspired aesthetic and plenty of enemies to mow your way through. Stupid Never Dies is what GPTRACK50 has been working on, and it comes to PC and PS5 next year.

Star Wars: Fate of the Old Republic isn't the KotOR remake

I know you're waiting on tenterhooks for news of that Knights of the Old Republic remake, but this isn't it. It's a whole new action RPG in the Star Wars universe, and it boasts the involvement of ex-BioWare bod Casey Hudson.

John Carpenter's Toxic Commando has a release date

Next, we got to see a snippet of the brutal and heavily 80s-inspired John Carpenter's Toxic Commando, which will be arriving on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S on March 12th.

Surprise! That statue was for Divinity

Hey, who'd have thunk? That mysterious statue out in the desert was for a new Divinity game by Larian Studios, so it looks like that's the developer's next big focus after the hugely successful Baldur's Gate 3.

4Loop is a Helldivers-esque co-op shooter

Next, it's 4Loop, a Helldivers-style co-op shooter in which you and your squad are constantly reprinted (hence the "loop" of the title) to do endless battle with robots. PC and PS5 for this one, but no release date.

Coven of the Chicken Foot looks whimsically fun

The Last of Us director Bruce Straley's new game is next, and Coven of the Chicken Foot looks...not a lot like that game, actually. It's a Last Guardian-style companion puzzler coming at some point in the future.

Ontos is Amnesia studio Frictional's new game

Frictional Games has developed a reputation for itself for making genuinely creepy, thought-provoking horror, so let's hope new sci-fi spook-'em-up Ontos continues that legacy. It'll arrive next year.

Hey, Leon's in Resident Evil Requiem!

Another of gaming's worst-kept secrets was revealed next: Leon Kennedy is in Resident Evil Requiem, and he's playable as well. February for this one, remember?

Order of the Sinking Star looks suitably mind-bending

Here's a puzzler for everyone who's smart enough to handle it (which, if I'm being honest, probably isn't me). Order of the Sinking Star is a reality-bending puzzle game coming sometime next year.

Exodus looks a little bit Mass Effect

Has Mass Effect left a hole in your life? Are you looking for a new sci-fi space opera to laugh and cry to? Exodus may well be the game for you. It's brought to you by Wizards of the Coast, and it's coming in early 2027.

Warlock: Dungeons & Dragons has those high fantasy vibes

Next, it's...erm, well, we don't really know what Warlock: Dungeons & Dragons is just yet. We will do by summer 2026, though, when a gameplay reveal has been promised.

Screamer proves once again that driving and storytelling can work

I'm honestly extremely glad that narrative racing games appear to be trying to make a comeback, and so is the beautifully-animated Screamer, apparently. March 26th for this one.

Control Resonant promises another mind-bending story

If you played the original Control, you'll know it was a wild and at least partly nonsensical (in a good way!) journey, and long-awaited sequel Control Resonant promises more of the same next year.

Gang of Dragon looks very Yakuza, which is apropos

Next, it's a trailer for Gang of Dragon, the debut game from Yakuza creator Toshihiro Nagoshi's new studio. Unbelievably, it looks a lot like Yakuza-slash-Like a Dragon, although there's sadly no release date.

Lego Batman: Legacy of the Dark Knight arrives in May

The new Lego Batman game, which retells many of the Dark Knight's most iconic stories in Lego form, is arriving on May 29th, and you can pre-order it now. Wahey!

Tomb Raider Catalyst is the next big Tomb Raider game

Cards on the table: I'm not really a pre-rendered game trailer fan. I want to see what the game plays like! That said, that's all we got for Tomb Raider Catalyst, but at least we got to see a new interpretation of Lara Croft. 2027 for this one.

Surprise! It's actually two Tomb Raider games

Crystal Dynamics announced a second Tomb Raider game next in the form of Tomb Raider: Legacy of Atlantis, a remake (yes, another one) of the first game in the series. It looks a bit more modernized this time around, though. 2026!

Hey, Forest 3 looks pretty weird

Endnight Games is working on a third Forest game, it turns out, and this one's taking...a more science fiction-y direction? It'll probably be a while before we hear from it again, at any rate.

Orbitals is one for classic anime fans

Next up, it's Orbitals, a rather beautiful-looking retro anime-style sci-fi adventure game that also appears to be co-op. It's coming exclusively to the Nintendo Switch 2 next year.

Diablo 4's next expansion is Lord of Hatred

Are you ready for yet more clicking on things to get EVEN BIGGER numbers and colors? Diablo 4: Lord of Hatred sure hopes you are. You can expect this one on April 28th.

Lords of the Fallen 2 is a Soulslike - who'd have thunk?

CI Games showcased Lords of the Fallen 2 next, and it's got pretty much exactly what you'd expect from a Soulslike, to wit: lots of monsters, lots of killing, and, uh, the Pet Shop Boys. 2026 is when this one is coming out.

Saros launches in April

Housemarque's next game, Saros, which continues the roguelite action trend of Returnal, is launching on April 30th, the studio announced last night. Get your pre-orders ready!

No Law has serious Cyberpunk 2077 vibes

At first, I thought No Law would be some kind of Cyberpunk 2077 expansion, but nope: it's a new game from Krafton and The Ascent's Neon Giant. You can wishlist it now across platforms!

Total War: Warhammer 40k is finally happening

It's a match made in heaven (or perhaps the Warp), and so the existence of Total War: Warhammer 40k probably shouldn't come as a surprise. You can expect it on PC and consoles, although we don't know when.

Ace Combat 8: Wings of Theve soars in next year

That's right: another Ace Combat game is coming! Ace Combat 8: Wings of Theve looks to continue the series' signature blend of high drama and, well, high drama when it launches next year.

Star Wars: Galactic Racer has podracing action for you

Hey, do you miss the glory days of Star Wars Episode I: Racer? If so, then Star Wars: Galactic Racer is the podracing game for you. It's launching next year!

Out of Words feels a bit Unravel-y

Next, it's puzzle-platformer Out of Words, which has a rather lovely (if very Unravel-esque) woolen aesthetic. You'll be able to check this one out next year as well.

Phantom Blade Zero is action-packed, and it has a release date

Action game Phantom Blade Zero was up next, and we've got a release date for this definitely-not-a-Soulslike, too: September 9th on both PC and PlayStation 5.

The Blue Bomber returns in Mega Man Dual Override

The good news: Mega Man is returning in a brand new sidescrolling adventure. The bad: we'll have to wait until 2027 to play it. Still, it looks like classic Mega Man, which is great.

Highguard is a free-to-play fantasy FPS from Respawn

If you were hoping for the return of Titanfall during this Game Awards, then sadly, you'll be disappointed. We did get to see a new free-to-play fantasy FPS called Highguard, though, which is launching in January.

We made it! That's everything that was announced during this year's Game Awards ceremony. Join us around the same time next year for more!

item.title: After a rough reveal, Deus Ex Remastered gets an indefinite delay with existing preorders refunded
item.content:encoded:
Might need some kind of machina for this one

When Deus Ex Remastered was revealed back in September, it quickly became apparent how Simply Not Great this thing looked. There was way too strong of a "we have to make this thing look new and modern and well lit" vibe to it that did not go down very well with pretty much anyway. It even tried to convince us that you'd need an RTX 2080 to run it at the recommended settings! The gall! And here we are, almost three months later, with word that the game has been delayed.

Not only has it been delayed, but it's been delayed indefinitely. Yesterday, developer Aspyr shared a statement on Bitter announcing the delay, writing that they've "listened to what you had to say, and in order to better meet fan expectations and deliver the best possible experience for players, Deus Ex Remastered will no longer launch on February 5, 2026. We look forward to sharing more updates with you when the time comes."

Thank you to the community for your feedback following the reveal of Deus Ex Remastered. We've listened to what you said, and in order to better meet fan expectations and deliver the best possible experience for players, Deus Ex Remastered will no longer launch on Feb. 5, 2026. pic.twitter.com/NhalyPLm8q

— Aspyr (@AspyrMedia) December 11, 2025

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Further than that, anyone that's preordered the game will receive a full refund. The statement doesn't provide any details other than that, nor when Aspyr expect to share any other details about the remaster.

If you were someone desperate to jump back into a slightly flashier version of Deus Ex (but as Mark noted at the time of the remaster's announcement, you can bag the OG for only £6, so I'm not sure why you'd want such a thing), I'd keep your expectations in check for now. Such an overhaul will take quite a while.

It is worth noting that it's not just the graphics that got a new look. There are supposed quality-of-life improvements like autosaves, faster loading, controller support, little things we take for granted now essentially. When the time comes, it might be a nice new way to play the game, but for now, put it at the back of your mind.

item.title: 'Orbitals' Brings Awesome-Looking Asymmetrical Co-Op Anime Antics To Switch 2 Next Year
item.content:encoded:
Cosmic conundrums

Keplar Interactive and Japanese indie dev Shapefarm have announced that their brand new intergalactic puzzle adventure, Orbitals, is coming exclusively to Switch 2 sometime in 2026.

Revealed during The Game Awards, which we shouldn't hold against it, Orbitals sees two players take on asymmetrical co-op tasks to stop cosmic storms from ruining their space station. Sounds quite tense. Set in a brand-new retro anime galaxy, the game is a debut effort from Shapefarm, and it's been built "from the ground up" for cooperative play, so we're looking forward to being treated to some smart puzzles, thanks.

You and your partner will set about utilising unique space tools, piloting a ship through meteor fields, or even just hanging out to revel in a retro anime vibe that's based off 1970s manga. So that's why the trailer, which you can see up top, looks so very cool.

Indeed, the devs have gone to the trouble of partnering up with Studio Massket, a storied Japanese animation house, to create a fully original anime world complete with hand-crafted cutscenes. Oh, and it's got full English and Japanese dubs (and you can check out the Japanese version of the trailer at the bottom of the page).

It's nice, too, to see a game that's aiming to utilise all the new tech capabilities we've got on Switch 2, with GameShare, GameChat, and all that caper used to further enhance the experience.

Here's some more info and some official screens to further whet your appetite.

Orbitals captures the warmth and style of classic Japanese anime, brought to life with authentic detail and clear reverence by the Tokyo-based development team at Shapefarm.

Developed in Unreal Engine 5, Orbitals takes full advantage of the Nintendo Switch 2 hardware to deliver an unforgettable co-operative experience regardless of your preferred way of connecting together.

Either by teaming up with two pairs of Joy-Con 2 controllers on a single Nintendo Switch 2 device for split-screen local co-op, using the system’s GameShare feature to share Orbitals with another local player on a compatible Nintendo Switch 2 or Nintendo Switch device, or by matchmaking online with their friends and taking advantage of the Nintendo Switch 2’s built-in microphone and GameChat for crystal-clear communications, players around the world can team up and save the day together as one inseparable team.

Liking the look of Orbitals? Let us know!

PJ is a staff writer across Hookshot Media. He's been playing video games pretty much nonstop since the early 1980s, which is ages ago. Favourite genres include RPGs, puzzle games and lovely big single player adventures of all kinds. The weirder the better.

item.title: Star Wars: Galactic Racer sounds like a Midi-chlorian-heavy MotorStorm, something I didn't know I craved
item.content:encoded:
All right, I've definitely got a weakness for Star Wars games which shift the camera away from all the glowy sword fights and space politics, instead zooming in on galactic ne'er-do-wells getting up to mischief. I blame my dad's influence. Star Wars Outlaws stuck that chord for me, and Star Wars: Galactic Racer looks like it'll combine similar appeal with the trump card of chaotic off-road racing.

Announced during last night's Geoffs, Galactic Racer's a speeder speedfest from Fuse Games - a new studio led by ex-Criterion devs with Burnout and Need For Speedy flavour to their CVs. Though, watching its trailer and reading through an interview Fuse co-founder Matt Webster and Lucasfilm Games vice president Douglas Reilly have given to the official Star Wars website, my brain's been taken to a different racing place.

The trailer shows off packs of landspeeders and speederbikes swooping and slamming as they hover through trails that wind through the likes of a ship graveyard on desert world Jakku and the snowy wilds of Ando Prime. It's obviously leaning into the podracing vibes we've seen videogamed in Star Wars Episode I: Racer, even starring Phantom Menace speedster Sebulba, but in practice, the action sounds like Evolution Studios' old PlayStation mud-fests.

"We’ve drawn real inspiration from runs-based games so the player will have meaningful, consequential decisions to be making on how they chose their path to become an elite racing pilot — from the vehicle they choose to start with, the upgrade choices they make to create a build that really suits their playstyle and what events they select in determining their path to become champion of the League," Webster said in the interview. "Along the way you’ll compete with rivals, journey to new planets, and master different classes of repulsor craft — or speeders — each with their own distinct capabilities.

"We have a range of racing repulsorcraft for players to discover in the game, each of which have unique handling characteristics to master. Speederbikes, for example, are fast and ferocious, you’ll be braking heavily into corners, really leaning in and then massive drops of acceleration as you power your way through the exit. Also notice that in many of our events, our different speeder classes race at the same time, with exciting physical interactions as those differing racing lines come together."

Given the off-roady courses, that last bit about routes aimed at the different strengths of different craft diverging and coming back together is the aspect that's put my mind back in Monument Valley. Obviously, it's not like Galactic Racer's floaty rides will be getting stuck in the mud or splattering through it with chunky tyres, but cutting through narrow chasms in your nimble skim speeder to avoid being side-swiped by a bulkier landspeeder on a more open track definitely is.

All in all, the prospect of battling through the underground racing scene as Shade - "a lone racer with a dream of glory and revenge" - has definitely got my engine running at this point.

If the same applies to you, Star Wars: Galactic Racer's wishlistable on Steam.

item.title: Free-to-play PvP shooter Highguard launches this January
item.content:encoded:
Highguard is a new PvP raid shooter from the creators of Apex Legends and Titanfall which mixes guns with magic, plus some light horseback riding.  You play as a Warden who must fight for the Shieldbreaker, which in turn lets you smash into the enemy base.

The rest of the game is being kept under wraps but we can see from the trailer it looks good, and while the hero character designs are impressive they do seem to fall in to the usual stereotypes. Maybe one day we will get a hulking, growly, muscle brute who’s actually a wizard with long-range attacks rather than a rage-filled, close combat animal.

The trailer also shows some of the abilities the heroes have and they are suitably splashy and spectacular and remind me of the Supers found in Destiny 2. In fact some of them seem very similar, the animations are very close, but I guess there’s only a finite number of ways you can wave your hands around to cast a spell.

There’s some horseback riding, but you can also ride a bear (don’t get any ideas), or a panther. Also in the mix is what appears to be medieval take on the Thundertank from Thundercats. The only thing that made me wince whilst watching the Highguard trailer was the blonde character shouting “Bring the heat”,  that phrase has been used so many times in video games it is cheesy as hell.

The game is free-to-play which should give a decent start but the world of F2P shooters is already packed with the likes of RedSec, Fortnite, Overwatch 2, and COD Warzone and we have seen many games try and break in to that market and fail

Highguard will launch on PS5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC via Steam on January 26th, 2026, will you be singing up to play?

item.title: ACE COMBAT 8: WINGS OF THEVE Announced for 2026 Launch, Will Feature Multiplayer Modes
item.content:encoded:
Bandai Namco Aces has announced ACE COMBAT 8: WINGS OF THEVE during The Game Awards 2025. About a year and a half ago, an actor's resume 'leaked' its existence, suggesting a 2025 launch, but the game will instead be released next year on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series S and X. Still, we don't suppose many fans of this franchise will complain. This is the first mainline installment in seven years, after all.

As you'd expect, the press release claims it will take the IP to new heights. Harnessing the power of Unreal Engine 5 in addition to proprietary technology, the studio promised players a visually stunning, ultra-realistic aerial thrill ride. It will feature an immersive campaign mode that places players in the role of an ace pilot, embroiled in an emotional tale of identity and duty as they fight for the survival of their homeland. ACE COMBAT 8: WINGS OF THEVE will also feature multiplayer modes that thrust players into high-speed aerial dogfights against friends and foes.

The press release notes that the new game continues the legacy of the ACE COMBAT franchise, which has consistently pushed the boundaries of game visuals and action-packed, arcade-inspired gameplay in the flight shooting genre. Players will fly various real-world fighter jets from around the globe in a game characterised by stunning visual detail and effects. They will navigate realistic expanses of clouds, finely rendered terrain and landscapes, and inclement weather. Bandai Namco Aces also teased thrilling cinematics and the option to view them from a first-person perspective, which could potentially enhance the immersion of the story.

The announcement trailer provides a first glimpse of the game's in-depth Campaign Mode, in which players take on the role of an ace pilot in Strangereal, a fictitious war-torn world. The weight of decisions, the pressure of command, and the bonds forged in battle will feel very real. With their nation, the Federation of Central Usea (FCU), occupied and its navy destroyed, players take on the role of the 'Wings of Theve' – a legendary ace whose name is synonymous with Theve, the capital of the FCU, and who is a symbol of hope for every citizen in their homeland. Joined by three new fighter pilots, they embark on a mission to reclaim their homeland and eliminate the threat to their people, carrying the hope of every FCU citizen and taking on the name of their capital city.

item.title: Nioh 3 to Get New Demo on PS5 & PC on January 29, 2026, and It Carries Over to the Full Game; Crossplay Is Missing
item.content:encoded:
During The Game Awards 2025, publisher KOEI TECMO and developer Team NINJA announced that a new demo of their upcoming dark samurai action RPG, Nioh 3, will be released on January 29, 2026 on PlayStation 5 and PC (via Steam). The previous demo, as you might recall, was only available for PS5. Players will be able to sharpen their blades in the new demo in solo mode or in online multiplayer mode with up to three other players. Cross-play is not supported for online multiplayer, according to the press release, and this limitation applies not only to the demo but also to the full game. After completing the demo, fans will be able to carry over their save data to the final game.

Pre-orders are now open. The Standard Edition is priced at $79.99, while the Digital Deluxe Edition costs $119.99. This version includes the Season Pass (also available for separate purchase), as well as the following items:

  • Nioh 3 season pass bonus "Chijiko Netsuke Charm" (accessory)
  • Infernal Weapons Set (14 types)
  • Kodama Netsuke Charm (accessory)

The season pass is a set including add-on DLCs. The DLCs include new stories, enemies, yokai, boss characters, and equipment. The aforementioned season pass bonus items will be released on the same date as the base game. Add-on DLC 1 is set to become available by the end of September 2026, and add-on DLC 2 is set to become available by the end of February 2027.

A SteelBook edition is also available to pre-order and includes the base game and two exclusive DLC bonuses. Players can also pre-order a special PlayStation 5 physical edition exclusively through the NIS America Store. The Nioh 3 TREASURE BOX includes the base game, a Scampuss Furball Netsuke Charm Keychain, a Nioh 3 Original Desk Pad, the Official Artbook, and a Nioh 3 Selection Soundtrack CD.

Additionally, new exclusive bonuses for players who purchase the game early have been revealed. These players will receive bonus armour sets inspired by protagonists from previous titles: the “Youngblood Armour (Samurai)”, worn by William in Nioh, and the “Lone Wolf’s Armour (Ninja)”, worn by Hide in Nioh 2. These items can be obtained by redeeming the “Hellfrost Armour Set” early purchase bonus in the game. Lastly, a special discount is available on the Steam version of Nioh: Complete Edition, which offers players a 90% discount on the first title in the franchise.

Nioh 3 launches on February 6, 2026 for PlayStation 5 and PC. According to Wccftech's Francesco De Meo, who recently played the game at a preview event, it feels like the culmination of every previous Team NINJA title. The developers also assured fans that the game won't feature sudden difficulty spikes.

item.title: Total War: Warhammer 40,000 devs detail future factions, and when you can expect official modding tools
item.content:encoded:
Plus, insight into when you can see more of the game

The future is here! Or, I guess it's around 40,000 years away, but that's still more or less here for the Total War series, which'll be tackling a futuristic setting for the first time in last night's reveal of a Warhammer 40,000 spin-off reveal. It's got most of what you'd expect, like those mean ole Space Marines, and big, dramatic, explosive battles with so much going on on screen you'll get a hernia. But there were a few details shared in a post-reveal blog post that go into some small bits that weren't a part of the big reveal.

Right at the bottom of said blog post is an FAQ, with the first notable question there being "where are the Chaos Space Marines?" As it stands, the only revealed factions so far are the regular Space Marines, Orks, Aeldari, and Astra Militarum. In response to that question, Creative Assembly explained that the Chaos Space Marines won't be there at launch, but they'll "absolutely" be a part of their plans "at some point, along with all the other iconic factions from the setting."

Then there's the question of modding. From right off the bat, the team wants to support modding on the Steam Workshop from launch, but it's the official modding tools you'll have to wait a while longer for. This is down to Creative Assembly's new Warcore engine, and they note that they'll have more details to share on that "close to launch." Oh, and don't worry, there won't be any blood DLC because the "41st Millennium is a setting of eternal war, so blood and dismemberment is key to creating an authentic experience."

The blog post also makes mention of a "small roundtable with members of the development team" coming next week on December 16th. Important to note that you shouldn't expect a big look at gameplay, it sounds like more of a light chat about the strategy game. A full look at its story and gameplay will apparently come in spring, so hang tight for now.

item.title: Ace Combat 8: Wings of Theve is a brand new entry in the series with a brand new trailer
item.content:encoded:
I know I really like Ace Combat, but in the world of gaming storylines, I couldn’t tell you one little detail about the somewhat crazy geo-political shenanigans that the series is known for. Still, we can all hope that the story becomes a touch more affecting with the announcement of the latest entry, Ace Combat 8: Wings of Theve, with its Top Gun-inspired aerial combat due for release at some point in 2026 and coming to PC, PS5 and Xbox Series X|S.

Coming from Project Aces and Bandai Namco, Ace Combat 8: Wings of Theve is a direct sequel to Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown which released all the way back in 2019. This time out, you’re a fighter pilot, adrift at sea in a rescue boat until the outdated aircraft carrier, Endurance, pulls you aboard. The ageing vessel, its decks crowded with refugees, has already retreated far from the front lines.

On this ship, you’re given a new name: “Wings of Theve”. A legendary ace, a symbol of hope, a name tied to Theve, the FCU capital. But, as it turns out, that legend was a lie; it was just a story made to keep morale alive. Now, you must carry that name and take to the skies with three new comrades at your side, fighting to reclaim your lost homeland.

Ace Combat 7 earned a hefty 9/10 when it launched, where I said, “In Ace Combat 7, dogfighting games have a new Top Gun. The VR sadly turned my stomach, but the series’ trademark action is bigger and better than ever, with the spectacular weather effects introducing a level of realism and drama that will win over any wannabe Mavericks.”

I definitely can’t wait to check out some more aerial combat, and I’ll certainly try to remember more of the story this time out, with the new first-person cutscenes looking like they’ll put you right at the centre of the action.

You can already wishlist Ace Combat 8: Wings of Theve over on Steam.
